thread.title: Brewers' dismal season ends with another loss to Cubs | Baseball
thread.title_full: Brewers' dismal season ends with another loss to Cubs | Baseball | ArcaMax Publishing

author: arcamax.com
title: Brewers' dismal season ends with another loss to Cubs | Baseball
text:
MILWAUKEE -- The Milwaukee Brewers' season ended as it started, with a loss at home.
In between, there were many other losses as the Brewers staggered to a disappointing 68-94 record.
It ended Sunday afternoon with a 3-1 loss at Miller Park to the playoff-bound Chicago Cubs, who swept the three-game series yet had to settle for the second wild-card spot in the National League and a showdown with division rival Pittsburgh on the road.
The Brewers were reminded quite often by the Cubs how far they have to go to be a contender again. In the 19 games the teams played this season, Chicago emerged with 14 victories.
The Cubs scored all of their runs in the first inning, with considerable help. Despite shutting out Chicago over the next eight innings, the Brewers couldn't mount a comeback.
Newcomer Jorge Lopez's first start at Miller Park began terribly as he hit Cubs leadoff hitter Austin Jackson with a pitch, then walked Chris Coghlan and Kris Bryant to load the bases with no outs.
Chicago first baseman Anthony Rizzo, who went 0-for-3 the previous evening in search for his 100th RBI, moved past that benchmark with a two-run single to right. Lopez prevented the inning from completely blowing up by getting Starlin Castro to ground into a double play as the third run of the inning scored.
Lopez had to battle over the next four innings but successfully did so to keep the Cubs from adding to their lead. He exited after the fifth, having allowed six hits, three walks and the three runs.
In the meantime, the Brewers were having little luck against Cubs veteran Dan Haren. They did scratch across a run in the third inning, when a bigger opportunity slipped away.
With Jean Segura (single, sacrifice by Lopez) on second base with two down, Scooter Gennett drew a walk. Shane Peterson followed with a drive to left that bounced over the wall for an RBI ground-rule double. Had the ball stayed in play, Gennett also would have scored but he was stranded when Adam Lind grounded out.
Khris Davis gave the Brewers hope for another run when he led off the fourth with a double to left. With one down, he was caught off base on Hernan Perez's comebacker to Haren, however, and tagged out in a run down.
After that, it was slim pickings for the Brewers' offense. They didn't come close to scoring another run, finishing with only two in the three-game series.
There was one noteworthy occurrence near the end of the game. Brewers reliever Will Smith struck out four hitters in the ninth, with Addison Russell reaching base by whiffing on a wild pitch.
(c)2015 Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
